total_revenue.context: Total revenue for Q3, up 21% year-on-year.

segments.name: Gaming

revenue.context: Gaming revenue for Q3, up 13% year-on-year and down 2% sequentially.

key_points: Initial sales of Turing-based GPUs and strong notebook sales drove YoY growth.
Mid-September launch of GeForce RTX series, the first gaming GPUs based on Turing architecture.
RTX technology delivers up to 2x the performance of Pascal and 6x more for ray-traced graphics.
High-end Pascal cards sold through, but midrange Pascal cards faced higher-than-expected inventory levels.

segments.name: Data Center

revenue.context: Data center revenue for Q3, up 58% year-on-year and up 4% sequentially.

key_points: Strong demand for Volta architecture products, including Tesla V100 and VGX systems.
Launch of Turing T4 Cloud GPU, which saw the fastest adoption of any server GPU.
T4 integrated into 57 server designs and available on Google Cloud Platform.
Updated TensorRT software stack and NVIDIA TensorRT Hyperscale Platform announced.

segments.name: Professional Visualization

revenue.context: Professional visualization revenue for Q3, up 28% year-on-year and up 9% sequentially.

key_points: Strength across desktop and mobile platforms.
Key industries include public sector, manufacturing, and architecture, engineering, and construction.
Launch of Quadro RTX 8000, 6000, and 5000 GPUs based on Turing architecture.

segments.name: Automotive

revenue.context: Automotive revenue for Q3, up 19% year-on-year and up 7% sequentially.

key_points: Growth in autonomous vehicle production and AI-based cockpit infotainment systems.
Volvo Cars selected NVIDIA DRIVE AGX Xavier for next-generation vehicles.
Development kit for DRIVE AGX Xavier started shipping in Q3.

revenue.context: Tegra processor revenue for Q3, down 3% year-on-year.
GPU revenue for Q3, up 25% year-on-year.

inventory.context: Inventory at the end of Q3.

accounts_receivable.context: Accounts receivable at the end of Q3.

gaap_gross_margin.context: Expected GAAP gross margin for Q4.

non_gaap_gross_margin.context: Expected non-GAAP gross margin for Q4.

strategic_initiatives: Launch of Turing-based GPUs and RTX technology.
Introduction of RAPIDS for GPU-accelerated data analytics and machine learning.
Expansion of NVIDIA's inference platform with TensorRT and T4 GPU.
Launch of NVIDIA RTX Server reference architecture for photoreal rendering.

market_opportunities.ray_traced_gaming: Growth opportunities in ray-traced gaming and rendering.

market_opportunities.ai_and_self_driving_cars: Expansion into AI and self-driving car markets.

market_opportunities.data_analytics: RAPIDS opens a $20 billion server market for data analytics and machine learning workloads.

introduction: Q3 revenue reached $3.18 billion, up 21% from a year earlier, with all 4 of our market platforms growing double digits.
Data center, professional visualization, and automotive all hit record levels.
Gaming was short of expectations as post crypto channel inventory took longer than expected to sell through.
gaming: Gaming revenue of $1.76 billion was up 13% YoY and down 2% sequentially.
Year-on-year growth driven by initial sales of our new Turing-based GPUs as well as strong notebook sales, which more than offset gaming console declines.
In mid-September, began shipping GeForce RTX series, the first gaming GPUs based on Turing architecture.
Turing RTX technology delivers up to 2x the performance of its predecessor, Pascal, and 6x more for ray-traced graphics.
First two GeForce RTX gaming cards, the 2080 Ti and the 2080, delivered 4K HDR gaming and 60 frames per second on advanced AAA titles.
Pipeline of upcoming games supporting NVIDIA RTX features is well on its way to establishing RTX as a game-changing architecture.
Post-crypto channel inventory took longer than expected to normalize, leading to weaker-than-expected sales of midrange Pascal gaming cards.
Pascal positioned as the GPU of choice in the midrange for the holidays; expect to work down channel inventories over the next quarter or two.
data_center: Data Center revenue was $792 million, up 58% YoY and up 4% sequentially.
Strong demand for Volta architecture products, including Tesla V100 and VGX systems.
Launch of Turing T4 Cloud GPU saw the fastest adoption of any server GPU; integrated into 57 server designs and available on Google Cloud Platform.
Updated TensorRT software stack and NVIDIA TensorRT Hyperscale Platform announced.
T4 delivers world record performance for deep learning inference and accelerates diverse cloud workloads.
Launch of NVIDIA RTX Server reference architecture, incorporating up to 8 Turing-based RTX 8000 GPUs for photoreal rendering.
Introduction of RAPIDS, GPU-accelerated data analytics and machine learning platform, opening up a $20 billion server market.
Strong industry support from developers like Adobe, ANSYS, Autodesk, Dassault, and others.
Increase in TOP500 supercomputer systems using NVIDIA GPUs by 48% from last year, including the #1 and #2 systems.
pro_vis: Professional Visualization revenue reached $0.305 billion, up 28% YoY and up 9% sequentially.
Strength extended across desktop and mobile platforms, key industries include public sector, manufacturing, and architecture, engineering, and construction.
Launch of Quadro RTX 8000, 6000, and 5000 GPUs based on Turing architecture.
Introduction of Quadro RTX 4000, the most advanced professional GPU priced under $1,000.
RTX Ray tracing transforming the visual effects industry, enabling researchers and developers to achieve photorealistic rendering, augmented reality, and virtual reality.
Key wins include Boeing, Google, LinkedIn, and Toyota for applications including AI and robotics.
RTX Ray tracing enabling faster photorealistic rendering and enhanced productivity for millions of creators and designers.
automotive: Automotive revenue was $0.172 billion, up 19% YoY and up 7% sequentially.
Growth driven by autonomous vehicle production and AI-based cockpit infotainment systems.
Volvo Cars selected NVIDIA DRIVE AGX Xavier for next-generation vehicles, delivering Level 2+ assisted driving features.
Development kit for DRIVE AGX Xavier started shipping in Q3, enabling millions of miles driven in virtual simulations.
Introduced NVIDIA Safety Force Field, a computational defensive driving framework to prevent collisions through simulation.
Positions NVIDIA in a $30 billion addressable market for autonomous vehicles by 2025, offering an end-to-end platform from AI computing infrastructure to simulation and in-car computing.
financials: Q3 GAAP gross margin was 60.4%, and non-GAAP gross margin was 61%, below our outlook due to a $57 million charge for prior architecture components and chips following the sharp falloff in crypto demand.
GAAP operating expenses were $863 million, and non-GAAP operating expenses were $730 million, up 28% year-on-year.
Continues to invest in key platforms driving long-term growth, including gaming, data center, and automotive.
GAAP net income was $1.23 billion, and EPS was $1.97, up 48% from a year earlier.
GAAP net income benefited from the reduction of $138 million in our U.S. tax reform transition tax amount as well as other discrete tax items.
Non-GAAP net income was $1.15 billion and EPS was $1.84, up 38% from a year ago, reflecting revenue growth and gross margin expansion as well as lower income tax expense.
Accounts receivable was $2.22 billion compared to $1.66 billion in the prior quarter as Turing's RTX shipments began in the latter part of the quarter.
Inventory at the end of the quarter was $1.42 billion compared to $1.09 billion in the prior quarter, reflecting the ramp in production of Turing products.
Quarterly cash flow from operations was $487 million.
Returned $1.95 billion to shareholders in fiscal year 2019 through a combination of quarterly dividends and share repurchases.
Announced a $0.01 increase in our quarterly dividend to $0.16 effective in Q4 of fiscal 2019.
Increased share repurchase authorization by $7 billion and intend to return an additional $3 billion to shareholders by the end of fiscal 2020.
q4_outlook: Expect revenue for Q4 to be $2.7 billion, plus or minus 2%.
GAAP gross margin expected to be 62.3% ±50 basis points.
Non-GAAP gross margin expected to be 62.5% ±50 basis points.
GAAP operating expenses expected to be approximately $915 million.
Non-GAAP operating expenses expected to be approximately $755 million.
GAAP and non-GAAP OI&E both expected to be income of $21 million.
GAAP and non-GAAP tax rates expected to be 8% ±1%, excluding discrete items.
Capital expenditures expected to be approximately $150 million.
Expect channel inventory normalization and seasonal trends to support revenue outlook.
investor_relations: Posted an investor presentation summarizing Q3 results and key highlights.
Committed to returning $3 billion to shareholders through dividends and buybacks by the end of fiscal 2020.
Upcoming events: Morgan Stanley Technology, Media and Telecom Conference on February 26; RBC Future of Mobility Conference on June 6; and NASDAQ Investor Conference on June 13.
